questions.text: Parathyroid gland post surgery is commonly transferred to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The parathyroid is commonly transferred to the brachioradialis muscle post-surgery. This will facilitate easy removal if there is disease recurrence after surgery. After parathyroidectomy or thyroid surgery, if the parathyroid gland needs to be autotransplanted, it is commonly implanted into the brachioradialis muscle of the forearm. This site is preferred because it is easily accessible for monitoring or reoperation if needed. Explanation of incorrect options: A. Triceps: Not commonly used for parathyroid autotransplantation. B. Biceps: Less commonly used compared to brachioradialis. C. Sartorius: Rarely used; it’s in the thigh and less practical for this purpose.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presented with complaints of heartburn, nausea, and bone pain. An x-ray of the hand shows subperiosteal resorption in the middle phalanx of the middle finger. Laboratory studies show elevated PTH levels. Which one of the following is not a feature of the above condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Osteosclerosis The clinical presentation and laboratory findings suggest primary hyperparathyroidism, characterized by elevated PTH levels, subperiosteal bone resorption, and symptoms like heartburn and bone pain. Among the options given, D. Osteosclerosis is not a feature of primary hyperparathyroidism. Instead, primary hyperparathyroidism is typically associated with generalized osteoporosis, renal calculi, and hypercalcemia.

choices.text: Upper parathyroid glands are superior to the junction of the inferior thyroid artery and RLN (recurrent laryngeal nerve)
Most common location of ectopic parathyroid glands is the paraesophageal
Lower parathyroid glands are inferior to the junction of the inferior thyroid artery and RLN (recurrent laryngeal nerve)
The superior parathyroid glands are located anterior to RLN (recurrent laryngeal nerve)

questions.text: A 58-year-old female presents to the clinic complaining of sweating, weight loss, and palpitations. A Tc99m Sestamibi scan revealed increased right superior parathyroid gland uptake. The patient underwent an exploration of neck and parathyroidectomy. All of the following are true about the parathyroid gland except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The superior parathyroid glands are located dorsal (posterior) to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) and superior to the junction of the inferior thyroid artery and RLN. In contrast, the lower parathyroid glands are found ventral (anterior) to the RLN and inferior to this junction. Approximately 85% of the parathyroid glands are typically located within 1 cm of the junction of the inferior thyroid artery and the RLN. The normal size of a parathyroid gland is comparable to that of a rice grain.

questions.text: What is the treatment for a 43-year-old female with loin pain, bone pain, elevated serum calcium and PTH levels, and increased uptake in all four parathyroid glands on a sestamibi scan?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Removal of 3 ½ glands The patient has primary hyperparathyroidism, indicated by elevated calcium and PTH levels, with a Sestamibi scan showing increased uptake in all four parathyroid glands, suggesting hyperplasia. Treatment involves initially correcting hypercalcemia with IV normal saline and furosemide, followed by neck exploration. For hyperplasia of all four glands, the approach is resection of three and a half glands or resection of all four glands with autotransplantation into the brachioradialis of the non-dominant arm. In contrast, a single parathyroid adenoma (85% of cases) and two adenomas (5%) are treated with resection.
